title: Andy Murray unveils Roger Federer as guest for his exhibition event in Scotland - and then warns him off deep fried Mars Bars
text:
Andy Murray unveils Roger Federer as guest for his exhibition event in Scotland - and then warns him off deep fried Mars Bars Murray announces Roger Federer will head to Scotland for his exhibition match Simon Briggs , Tennis Correspondent 9 February 2017 • 1:54pm 
A ndy Murray warned Roger Federer to stay off the deep-fried Mars Bars as he unveiled the Swiss champion as the big-name guest for his exhibition event in November. 
This will be Federer’s first visit to Scotland, and Murray was concerned that the local cuisine might be too much for the great man’s palate. 
Asked what advice he might pass on to his famous invitee, Murray replied “Don’t try the fried Mars Bars. I tried one last year and it was horrific.” 
In a press conference held today in east London, Murray added – more seriously - that he might consider taking longer breaks from the game after his early exit from the Australian Open. Murray suffered an early exit at the Australian Open 
T he year’s first grand slam turned into a disappointment for Murray, whose fourth-round conqueror – world No 50 Mischa Zverev – was the lowest-ranked opponent he has lost to at a major since he was 18. There was a theory in the locker-room that the exertions of 2016, which found Murray winning the last five events he contested, had caught up with him. Federer v Nadal final pics 
“It is incredible what he [Federer] did in Australia after such a long break,” said Murray. “In tennis we play such a lot during the year and sometimes coming to an event fresh can be a huge advantage. It was the same for Rafa. Maybe that is something we can all learn from. 
“He’s just extremely popular,” added Murray of Federer, whose appearance at Andy Murray Live will take him to Scotland for the first time. 
“He’s obviously one of the best players who’s ever played the game. It’s not just how much he won but also the way that he plays and the way that he carries himself. He’s just really popular everywhere. Watch | Roger Federer defeats Rafael Nadal to win Australian Open 00:28 
“I think hopefully we’ll play some good tennis, but I think for tennis fans all over the world just seeing him play right now in different places – he said a few years ago that he wants to try to go to places where he’s not been so that all his fans can watch him - is great.” 
A ndy Murray Live presented by SSE will be played in Glasgow on Nov 7, featuring not only the elder Murray and Federer, but also his younger brother Jamie, Tim Henman and doubles trickster Mansour Bahrami. 
“Last year was such a fantastic night,” said Murray, “and to raise over £300,000 for Unicef and Young People's Futures in our first year was amazing. This year is going to be even bigger and better and I am so pleased to be able to bring Roger to play in Scotland for the first time – and he will get a chance to see for himself how enthusiastic Scottish fans are. We are very lucky. This year to have Roger involved is incredible.”
